column3: how much; how many; several; a few
column5:
å‡  (jÇ)

This word is used to ask about the number or quantity of something, and is often translated as "how many" or "how much." It is used to inquire about a small or indefinite number.



å°‘ (shÇo)

This word means "few" or "little," and is used to describe a small quantity or number. It is used to indicate a scarcity or insufficiency of something.



For example, you can use å‡  (jÇ) to ask "How many apples do you want?" or "How much water do you need?" However, you would use å°‘ (shÇo) to say "There are few people in the room" or "There is little time left."

ä¸ (bÃ¹)

This word is used to negate verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. It is the general negation word in Chinese and is used to express the absence or opposite of a certain action or state.



æ²¡ (mÃ©i)

This word is used to indicate the absence or lack of something in the past tense. It is specifically used to negate actions or states that occurred in the past.



For example, you can use ä¸ (bÃ¹) to say "I don't want to go" or "He is not happy." On the other hand, you would use æ²¡ (mÃ©i) to say "I didn't eat breakfast" or "She didn't come to the party."
